title_en: Presents the Wave Theory of Light

summary.text_en: In 1678, Huygens first presented his revolutionary 'Wave Theory of Light' to the French Academy of Sciences in Paris. As a direct rival to Newton's 'Corpuscular Theory', it argued light was a wave propagating through a medium called the 'aether'. He proposed 'Huygens's Principle' (every point on a wavefront is a source of new wavelets) and used it to perfectly derive the laws of reflection and refraction. His theory was formally published in 1690 as 'TraitÃ© de la LumiÃ¨re'.
key_points_en: First to mathematically derive the laws of reflection and refraction

story.text_en: Huygens's genius was the 'wavelet' idea. Imagine a flat water wave hitting a barrier with a small hole. The water that goes through the hole spreads out as a new *circular* ripple. Huygens said *every point* on a wavefront of light is doing the same thingâ€”emitting its own tiny 'wavelet'. The 'envelope' of all these wavelets (the tangent line that touches all of them) becomes the new wavefront. This simple geometric model not only explained propagation, but it perfectly *derived* why light bends when it enters glass (refraction)â€”because, he argued, light moves *slower* in glass.

fun_facts.text_en: Because of Isaac Newton's immense authority (who favored the particle theory), Huygens's wave theory was largely ignored and overshadowed for over 100 years.
Newton's particle theory struggled to explain 'diffraction' (bending of light) and thin-film colors (like soap bubbles). Huygens's wave theory (when fully developed) explained them perfectly.

simple_explanation.text_en:
Newton thought light was a stream of tiny 'bullets' (particles). Huygens thought light was a 'ripple in a pond' (a wave). Newton's theory explained shadows well, but struggled to explain why light *bends* when it enters water (refraction).
Huygens's theory: Imagine a line of soldiers (the light wave) marching from pavement (air) into mud (glass) at an angle. The first soldiers to hit the mud *slow down*, while the soldiers still on the pavement keep going fast. This *must* cause the entire line of soldiers to *pivot* and change direction. He perfectly explained refraction with this wave model.

applications.text_en: Huygens's Principle is the foundation of modern physical optics, used to explain and calculate the phenomena of 'diffraction' and 'interference'.

applications.text_en: His mathematical derivation of the law of refraction is fundamental to the design of all modern optical instruments (camera lenses, telescopes, microscopes).

impact.text_en: Though suppressed for a century by Newton's authority, Huygens's theory was resurrected in the early 1800s by Thomas Young and Augustin-Jean Fresnel. Young's 'double-slit experiment' proved definitively that light *was* a wave. Huygens's wave theory eventually triumphed over Newton's particle theory (until Einstein's photoelectric effect forced the modern 'wave-particle duality'). 'TraitÃ© de la LumiÃ¨re' is a foundational text of physics equal to Newton's 'Opticks'.

influenced.contribution_en: Thomas Young (whose 'double-slit experiment' finally provided the definitive proof for Huygens's wave theory)
Augustin-Jean Fresnel (who mathematized Huygens's Principle to precisely explain diffraction)
Einstein (whose 'photon' concept ultimately reconciled Huygens's waves and Newton's particles into 'wave-particle duality')

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Huygens established the great rival theory to Newton's optics, and his deep insights about 'waves' remain a fundamental tool for physicists today.

quiz.question_en: What was the fundamental disagreement between Huygens's 'Wave Theory' and Newton's 'Particle Theory'?
options_en: Whether light is a particle or a wave
Whether the Earth orbits the Sun
Whether gravity is an inverse-square law
quiz.explanation_en: This was the central debate in physics at the end of the 17th century. Newton (`newton_opticks_1704`) argued light was made of tiny 'bullets' (corpuscles), while Huygens argued it was a 'ripple' (wave) traveling through an 'aether'.
